Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Integrated Research and Education in Self-powered Micro-sensing for Embedded and Implantable Structural Health Monitoring

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
The research objective of this Faculty Early Career Development (CAREER) award is investigating novel battery-less, self-powered micro-sensors that can operate at fundamental limits of energy harvesting (picowatt-nanowatt power consumption) and hence can be used for long-term monitoring of fatigue in civil, mechanical and biomechanical structures. A novel piezoelectricity driven ionized-impact hot electron injection(p-IHEI) principle which exploits the computational primitives inherent in the interface physics between piezoelectric transducers and floating-gate transistors. The p-IHEI principle is being used for self-powered computation of mechanical usage statistics (strain, strain-rate, acceleration, dwell-time and spectral statistics) which are useful to prognosticate fatigue. Also a novel piezoelectricity driven harmonic radar where the piezoelectric element scavenges ambient mechanical noise to amplify and reflect harmonics of any impinging radio-frequency signals. This principle bypasses many of the signal processing steps in a conventional radio-frequency identification technique and has the potential for interrogation distances beyond 100m.

Battery-less micro-sensors will be developed which could become an integral part of the next generation of "smart" structures that can self-diagnose damage and fatigue before the occurrence of any catastrophic failure. The outreach component of this project is focused on developing an electrical-civil-engineering forum in the area of electronic sensing systems for structural health monitoring. This forum is being used to train graduate and undergraduate students and students belonging to under-represented communities.

ProgramReference.Text: SENSORS AND SENSOR SYSTEMS FOR CIS

POR.DRECONTENT:
Physical structures such as bridges, roadways, rotor blades and prosthetics will degrade over time from long term structural stress.  Understanding the details of that stress over time for an individual element can provide critical data on predicting failure and scheduling maintenance or replacement.  A monitoring device strategically embedded into these structures can provide significant long term safety improvement and cost reduction possibilities.  The Piezo-Floating-Gate-based (PFG) battery-less Structural Health Monitoring (SHM) technology developed in this project addresses these structural monitoring concerns.  It combines novel circuits with piezoelectric transducers that act as both the sensor and the harvester of operational power for the sensor. A key feature of the PFG sensor are floating-gate sensing circuits that compute and store cumulative statistics of the strain-rates and stresses while achieving operational power limits not possible with any competing SHM sensor technology.  The project investigated variants of the PFG sensor that can operate at power levels less than a few nanowatts which can be easily harvested from a miniature piezoelectric transducer. This enables PFG sensors to be embedded within civil structures (e.g., bridges, pavement, buildings, dams, and levees), vehicles, rotating machines (e.g., wind-turbines) and biomedical implants. Stored data, retrieved by commercial off-the-shelf (COTS) radio-frequency identification (RFID) technology, are used to monitor and predict the onset of structural fatigue and to remotely configure the sensor. Applications of the PFG sensing technology include early detection and prediction of structural or mechanical failure which can significantly reduce maintenance costs and, ultimately prevent loss of life.

We have demonstrated that the PFG sensor can be used to monitor progression of damage in steel and concrete structures. A variant of the sensor (see accompanying image) has been deployed on the Mackinac Bridge in Michigan and is currently being evaluated for monitoring the health of specific bridge components.  We have also demonstrated that the PFG sensing technology can be used for designing wearable sensors, activity monitors and smart orthopedic implants. We have shown that the sensor could be embedded inside sport helmets and can continuously monitor and log the statistics of different levels of helmet impacts which could be useful for prognosticating onset of mild traumatic brain injuries (MTBIs) or concussions. In another study we have shown that the self-powered sensor could be used to differentiate between different conditions of bone-healing after a traumatic fracture. The data obtained from the sensor could be used by orthopedic surgeons in determining the functional load of a bone and hence could lead to better surgical outcomes.

The project has resulted in 14 journal papers, 13 conference papers and 1 book chapter. Two of the conference papers have received best paper awards and two other conference papers have received honorary mention awards. The project has resulted in 2 Ph.D. (1 female student) and 1 M.S. dissertations. Additionally, the project has provided training opportunities for three other Ph.D. students (1 female student). The project has resulted in three senior undergraduate design projects and the REU funds solicited through this project have resulted in one undergraduate independent study project. The PFG sensor technology being developed in this project has resulted in 5 issued U.S. patents. The technology is being commercialized by a startup company.
